DOC.HEAD: Murder Investigation Reopened After Civil Verdict Against Marcoses
DOC.TEXT: The investigation of the 1981 murders of two Filipino union leaders has been reopened after a civil trial found the late Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos liable for their deaths, a prosecutor said. The victims, Silme Domingo and Gene Viernes, worked in this country against Marcos, and their survivors claimed they were killed on orders from the Philippines. Police laid their deaths to union activities and three men were convicted. On Thursday, after meetings with attorneys for the dead men's families, the King County Prosecutors Office announced the probe would be reopened. ``We plan on taking a very serious look at the matter,'' said prosecutor's spokesman Dan Donohoe. The follow-up investigation should take about two months, Donohoe said. Last week the families of Domingo and Viernes won a civil suit in U.S. District Court here against the estate of Marcos, who died in September, and his widow, Imelda. The civil jury decided that Marcoses were conspirators in the deaths of the two men and were negligent in failing to control their intelligence agents in the United States. The families were awarded more than $15 million. After the trial, Seattle attorney Michael Withey, who represented the families, said the survivors wanted criminal charges filed against the man whose gun was used in the killings in light of evidence presented in their civil suit. The gun belonged to Constantine ``Tony'' Baruso, 61, of Seattle, who was never charged in the case. Baruso was president of the Alaska Cannery Workers Union when Domingo and Viernes were gunned down at the union's Seattle headquarters. Baruso and Dr. Leonilo Malabed, a San Francisco physician who allegedly managed an intelligence fund for Marcos, also were named in the civil suit. Baruso and Malabed waived their right to a jury trial and U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein has yet to rule on their part of the case. In a related matter, attorneys defending Mrs. Marcos in a federal racketeering case in New York have discussed a plea bargain, but are preparing for the March 14 trial anyhow. The talks with prosecutors were ``preliminary chitchat'' and haven't led to any sort of deal for her to plead guilty to lesser charges, said Mrs. Marcos's lawyer, John J. Tigue. The charges stem from allegations she and her late husband siphoned more than $100 million from the Philippines treasury and funneled it into this country for the purchase of New York real estate and art. The prosecutor, Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella, refused to comment on the negotiations.
